content.text: Disclosure controls
Disclosure controls reveal and hide information and functionality related to specific controls or views.

content.description: Two-state illustration showing disclosure control behavior. Left side shows 'Collapsed' state with a downward-pointing chevron icon on a coral/salmon colored rounded rectangle background. Right side shows 'Expanded' state with an upward-pointing chevron icon on a larger coral/salmon colored rounded rectangle that has expanded to reveal additional content area below it.
subjects: Collapsed disclosure control with down chevron
Expanded disclosure control with up chevron
Comparison of two states side by side
content.composition: Horizontal side-by-side comparison. Left side labeled 'Collapsed' shows a smaller rounded rectangle with chevron pointing down. Right side labeled 'Expanded' shows a taller rounded rectangle with chevron pointing up, demonstrating the expanded content area.
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration demonstrating UI state change
content.contextualRelevance: Hero illustration introducing the concept of disclosure controls showing their two primary states - collapsed and expanded

content.text: Best practices

Use a disclosure control to hide details until they're relevant. Place controls that people are most likely to use at the top of the disclosure hierarchy so they're always visible, with more advanced functionality hidden by default. This organization helps people quickly find the most essential information without overwhelming them with too many detailed options.

emphasis.boldText: Use a disclosure control to hide details until they're relevant.

content.text: Disclosure triangles

A disclosure triangle shows and hides information and functionality associated with a view or a list of items. For example, Keynote uses a disclosure triangle to show advanced options when exporting a presentation, and the Finder uses disclosure triangles to progressively reveal hierarchy when navigating a folder structure in list view.

content.description: Finder-style list view showing three folders with disclosure triangles. Each row shows a folder icon (blue folder) with the folder name beside it. Disclosure triangles appear to the left of each folder, pointing to the right (indicating collapsed state).
content.composition: Vertical list layout with three rows. Each row contains: right-pointing disclosure triangle (gray chevron), blue folder icon, folder name text.
content.technicalDetails: macOS Finder-style list view with expandable folders
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates disclosure triangles in a real-world context showing folder hierarchy navigation

content.text: A disclosure triangle points inward from the leading edge when its content is hidden and down when its content is visible. Clicking or tapping the disclosure triangle switches between these two states, and the view expands or collapses accordingly to accommodate the content.
Provide a descriptive label when using a disclosure triangle. Make sure your labels indicate what is disclosed or hidden, like "Advanced Options."

emphasis.boldText: Provide a descriptive label when using a disclosure triangle.

content.text: For developer guidance, see NSButton.BezelStyle.disclosure.
Disclosure buttons

A disclosure button shows and hides functionality associated with a specific control. For example, the macOS Save sheet shows a disclosure button next to the Save As text field. When people click or tap this button, the Save dialog expands to give advanced navigation options for selecting an output location for their document.

A disclosure button points down when its content is hidden and up when its content is visible. Clicking or tapping the disclosure button switches between these two states, and the view expands or collapses accordingly to accommodate the content.

content.description: macOS Save dialog sheet in collapsed state. Shows a minimal save interface with 'Save As' text field containing 'Untitled', a 'Tags' field, a 'Where' dropdown showing 'All Projects' with a disclosure button (down chevron) next to it, and Cancel/Save buttons at the bottom.
content.composition: Vertical form layout typical of macOS sheets. Fields stacked vertically with labels on the left. Disclosure button appears as a small down-chevron button adjacent to the Where dropdown.
content.technicalDetails: macOS Save sheet in collapsed/minimal mode, before disclosure button is clicked
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates disclosure button in a real-world macOS Save dialog context

content.text: Place a disclosure button near the content that it shows and hides. Establish a clear relationship between the control and the expanded choices that appear when a person clicks or taps a button.

emphasis.boldText: Place a disclosure button near the content that it shows and hides.

content.text: Use no more than one disclosure button in a single view. Multiple disclosure buttons add complexity and can be confusing.

emphasis.boldText: Use no more than one disclosure button in a single view.

content.text: For developer guidance, see NSButton.BezelStyle.pushDisclosure.
Platform considerations
No additional considerations for macOS. Not supported in tvOS or watchOS.
iOS, iPadOS, visionOS
Disclosure controls are available in iOS, iPadOS, and visionOS with the SwiftUI DisclosureGroup view.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page for Disclosure Controls - UI components that reveal and hide information and functionality. Covers two types: disclosure triangles (for hierarchical content like folder lists) and disclosure buttons (for expanding/collapsing specific controls like save dialogs). Includes best practices, platform-specific guidance, and developer resources.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Brief introduction defining disclosure controls as UI elements that reveal and hide information related to specific controls or views.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Guidelines for using disclosure controls: hide details until relevant, place commonly-used controls at top of hierarchy, keep advanced functionality hidden by default.

sections.title: Disclosure triangles
sections.summary: Detailed explanation of disclosure triangles - used for hierarchical content like folder structures. Points inward when collapsed, down when expanded. Examples include Keynote export options and Finder list view.

sections.title: Disclosure buttons
sections.summary: Detailed explanation of disclosure buttons - used for expanding specific controls. Points down when collapsed, up when expanded. Primary example is macOS Save dialog. Limit to one per view.

designDecisions.decision: Different arrow directions for triangles vs buttons
designDecisions.rationale: Triangles (hierarchical): right when collapsed, down when expanded. Buttons (inline): down when collapsed, up when expanded. This matches their use contexts.
